quizzes.title: History Quiz: Film and Maryland
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, troops, maryland. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which film won the Best Picture award at the 2006 Academy Awards?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Crash

questions.question: On May 28, 2006 Barry Bonds hit his 715th career homerun against which National League team?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Colorado Rockies

questions.question: Approximately how long was The Spanish-American War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 3-4 months

questions.question: Which battle, fought in Europe during WWII, started on December 16, 1944?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Battle of the Bulge

questions.question: The United States gained almost half of the territory of Mexico after the Mexican War from 1846–1848.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: In which European country were the 2006 Winter Olympics held?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Italy

questions.question: In World War II, 80% of the deaths were on the Allied side.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: North Vietnamese troops entered this South Vietnamese city, marking the unofficial end to the Vietnam War in 1975.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saigon

questions.question: The Cold War was one of the deadliest wars of all time.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Who was President of the USA when the Korean War began?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Harry Truman

questions.question: Was 2006 a leap (intercalary) year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: No

questions.question: Which war, fought in the 20th century, is sometimes referred to as The Forgotten War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Korean War

questions.question: The 2006 film See No Evil, released on May 19, stars what famous WWE wrestler?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kane

questions.question: Which northern state was last to make slavery illegal?

options.text: They all made it illegal at the same time

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New Jersey

questions.question: The North and South (between Maryland and Pennsylvania) were separated by what famous line?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Mason-Dixon Line

quizzes.title: History Quiz: War and Leader
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, leader, supporters. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This German military leader led the Sixth Army at the siege of Stalingrad. After months of siege, he was defeated and surrendered to the Russians.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Friedrich Paulus

questions.question: The Allies and Axis were the two main opponent powers in the Second World War. Which of these leaders and his country were on the side of the Axis powers?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Benito Mussolini

questions.question: In August 1944, the German forces in Paris surrendered to this French general who led a military unit from Normandy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leclerc

questions.question: This politician was the British Prime Minister who declared war on Germany in 1939.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Neville Chamberlain

questions.question: What event sparked the beginning of the United States War on Terror?

options.text: George W. Bushs victory in the 2000 election

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The terrorist attacks of September 11

questions.question: One of these historically influential political books was first published in February 1848. Its authors are Friedrich Engels and Karl Marx.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Communist Manifesto

questions.question: In February 1997 the first movie without commercial interruption was shown on US TV. This is the movie.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Schindlers List

questions.question: The attack on Pearl Harbour was carried out on December 7, 1941, causing the United States to enter the war on the side of the Allies. Who was president of the USA at that time?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Franklin D. Roosevelt

questions.question: Which of the following is the longest war in American history?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Vietnam War

questions.question: In February 1992 this treaty was signed. It established the European Union.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maastricht Treaty

questions.question: Operation Torch was planned to bring Morocco and Algiers under the Allies’ domination. Who was the general in charge of the operation?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dwight Eisenhower

questions.question: This man became U.S. Secretary of State after the Second World War. He developed a reconstruction plan, later named after him, to help the European countries recover after the war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Marshall

questions.question: Which of the following leaders was not present at  The Yalta Conference that took place in February 1945.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mao Zedong

questions.question: During World War II, this politician was the powerful leader of the Soviet Union, the country which suffered a record death toll in the war.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joseph Stalin

questions.question: This major Nazi leader, called by his supporters “Fuhrer” (leader), committed suicide in his bunker on April 30, 1945 in order not to be caught by the Allied forces.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Adolf Hitler

quizzes.title: History Quiz: February and Year
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, actor, crawford. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: In what year did the following events take place: Jonas Salk began testing his polio vaccine on volunteers, including his wife, his children and himself. The first animal, a tadpole, was cloned. The New York Yankees defeated the Brooklyn Dodgers in the World Series.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1952

questions.question: He made films from 1916 to 1939 and was married to Joan Crawford. His fathers name helped him launch his career, however Charlie Chaplin took a liking to him and the rest is history. What is the name of this actor who passed away in 2000?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Douglas Fairbanks Jr.

questions.question: The Battle of Stalingrad ended in February 1943.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: This actor, who died in 2000, played the role of Major Frank Burns on the TV series M.A.S.H.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Larry Linville

questions.question: In February of this year, the last episode of M*A*S*H was broadcast.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1983

questions.question: His first film role was The Kentuckian. His Broadway appearance in Neil Simons Odd Couple launched his career, but many remember him as one of the Grumpy Old Men. Who was this great actor?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Walter Mattheau

questions.question: In February 1952, the first Dont Walk sign was installed in this city.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New York City

questions.question: American cartoonist and creator of the comic strip Peanuts, Charles Schulz died in 2000.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The Yalta Conference ended in February 1945 . Do you know when it started?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: February 1945

questions.question: Which one of these events did not happen in the same year as the others?

options.text: The novel Peyton Place was published
Barry Gordy, Jr. invested $700 in founding Motown Records
Allen Ginsberg publishes the book Howl and Other Poems
Elvis Presley recorded the song Hound Dog

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Barry Gordy, Jr. invested $700 in founding Motown Records

questions.question: What star of Willow”  who passed away in 2000, founded the organization Little People of America in 1957?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Billy Barty

questions.question: The greatest fame for this actress, who passed away in 2000, came when she starred as Margaret Pynchon opposite Edward Asner in Lou Grant.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nancy Marchand

questions.question: In February 1924 President Woodrow Wilson died at this age.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 67

questions.question: The English director Alfred Hitchcocks first suspense film was released in February 1927. This was the name of the movie.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Lodger

questions.question: The first book edition of the detective story, The Valley of Fear, was released in February 1915. This is its author.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Poisoning and Music
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, theory, agatha. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which list contains only countries which formed the European Economic Community?

options.text: Spain, France, Austria, West Germany, Finland, and Portugal
Denmark, Sweden, The Netherlands, England, Belgium, and Luxembourg
Sweden, France, Italy, Austria, West Germany, and Spain
France, West Germany, Italy, The Netherlands, Belgium, and Luxembourg

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: France, West Germany, Italy, The Netherlands, Belgium, and Luxembourg

questions.question: Who commanded the three B-52 Stratofortresses which made the first globe-circling nonstop flight in 1957?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Major General Archie J. Old

questions.question: Who was the first person to be U.S. President of 50 states?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Eisenhower

questions.question: Until the French Revolution, this torture device was used to execute those accused of treason. It was also used on nobles to provide a swift and humane death.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Guillotine

questions.question: Which Ohio-born singer was famous with the hits Music! Music! Music!, Molasses, Molasses, and Youll Never Get Away?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Teresa Brewer

questions.question: Which of these events did not occur in 1957?

options.text: Sputnik III was launched and circled the Earth eleven times.
Leave It to Beaver, a TV show about  idyllic American life, first aired.
Charles Van Doren won $129,000 on the TV show Twenty-One.
The great Jackie Robinson retired from baseball

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sputnik III was launched and circled the Earth eleven times.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not correct?

options.text: Burt Lancaster starred in Vera Cruz, His Majesty OKeefe and Apache.
Expresso Bongo, Rock, Rock, Rock,  and Hot Rod Girl were all popular teenage movies in the 1950s.
The movie The Third Man was a financial flop when it  was released in 1951.
The 1955 movie,Marty, became the shortest film to win the Best Movie Oscar.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The movie The Third Man was a financial flop when it  was released in 1951.

questions.question: A fictional case of poisoning is observed in Agatha Christies And Then There Were None. In the novel, this character dies of poisoning.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Emily Brent

questions.question: One of the most popular fictional cases of poisoning occurs in the movie Arsenic and Old Lace, based on a play by this playwright.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Joseph Kesselring

questions.question: Which one of these events did not happen in 1955?

options.text: The McGuire Sisters have a #1 hit with Sincerely.
Rosa Parks refuses to give up her seat to a white woman in Montgomery, Alabama.
The Korean War is formally ended.
The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations merged

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Korean War is formally ended.

questions.question: Clare Boothe Luce (the American ambassador to Italy in the years just following World War II) died of arsenic poisoning.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Arsenic became a popular murder weapon in the Middle Ages, because symptoms resembled those of this disease.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cholera

questions.question: One of the most famous cases of poisoning is that of the Bulgarian Georgi Markov, who was poisoned by ricin. The latter was inserted into his body through this.

options.text: Eating a cake with ricin in it

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Stabbing with an umbrella

questions.question: There is a theory that Napoleon Bonaparte was poisoned with this substance.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Arsenic

questions.question: Which of these events did not  happen in 1950?

options.text: CBS got an FCC license to broadcast in color nation-wide.
Both Pillsbury and general Mills begin selling cake mixes.
General Dwight D. Eisenhower is elected President.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is elected President.

quizzes.title: Knowledge Quiz: Victims and Device
quizzes.description: Test your knowledge knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Knowledge, satan, nixon. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This mobile chamber was used all over Europe as a final resting place for criminals who survived other torture devices. The victims of this device would often starve to death.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The hanging cage

questions.question: In 1970, in a span of 72 hours, how many women made the FBIS 10 Most Wanted List?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 3

questions.question: Tin soldiers and Nixon coming
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kent State University

questions.question: Name the first great Greek tragic playwright who is now acknowledged as the Father of Drama?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Aeschylus

questions.question: This device was commonly used on witches who were believed to be carrying the Satan’s child.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The saw

questions.question: What  woman became the third female to make the FBIs 10 Most Wanted List on August 18th 1970 when she went on the run after her alleged participation in the kidnapping and murder of Judge Harold Harley from the Marin County Hall of Justice?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Angela Davis

questions.question: This torture device was used to rip the victim’s flesh to shreds. Once this was accomplished, the victim would be left to dangle alive, with arms bound, left at the mercy of flies and other insects.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cats paws

questions.question: Which Athenian politician and general led the disastrous attack on Spartan bases in Sicily?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alcibiades

questions.question: The head crusher was used as a swift and humane form of execution for the nobleman. It was designed in such a manner that upon impact it would cause immediate death of its victim.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: False

questions.question: Who was the father of Alexander the Great?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Philip II

questions.question: This instrument of torture was thrust into the victims’ chin and sternum rendering them motionless.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Heretics Fork

questions.question: Just like Ivory Soap, his product was supposed to be over 99% pure. This gentleman, the grandson of a United States Senator, was the first underground chemist to produce pure LSD in mass quantity. Who was the sound man and chemist for the Grateful Dead?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Owsley Stanley

questions.question: This pyramid-shaped seat was used to extract confessions from the victims who were placed on top of it.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Judas Cradle

questions.question: Which Greek historian is known as the Father of History?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Herodotus

questions.question: He was one of the founders of the YIPPIES and helped announce the candidacy of Pigasus the Pig in Chicago during the 1968 Democratic National Convention. Who was the author of Steal This Book?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Abbie Hoffman

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Period and Year
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, leader, bronze. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Issued during the Victorian period, it is the name of the worlds first official adhesive postage stamp.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Penny Black

questions.question: He served as the head of the London Metropolitan Police during the period of the Jack the Ripper Murders.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sir Charles Warren

questions.question: This British engineer is best known as the creator of the Great Western Railway, during the Victorian Age.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Isambard Kingdom Brunel

questions.question: This vessel, one of the symbols of progress during the Victorian Era, was the first steam ship purposely built for Atlantic crossing.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: SS Great Western

questions.question: This Victorian politician, best remembered as the originator of the modern police force, sought to repeal the Corn Laws as a measure to fight the Irish potato famine.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sir Robert Peel

questions.question: Who was the faithful wife of Odysseus who waited 20 years for his return from the Trojan War?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Penelope

questions.question: Who was the king of Sparta and leader of the 300 Spartans at the famous battle at Thermopylae?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Leonidas

questions.question: Who was the statesman who re-codified the laws of Athens to make them more humane, and set the city on the road to democracy?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Solon

questions.question: This person attempted to assassinate Queen Victoria during her first pregnancy.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Edward Oxford

questions.question: This woman was a Victorian era feminist, especially concerned with the welfare of working girls.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Josephine Butler

questions.question: Name Alexander the Greats favorite horse.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bucephalus

questions.question: Name the British socialist intellectual movement, among whose members was the famous Irish playwright Bernard Shaw.

options.text: The Fellowship of the New Life

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fabian Society

questions.question: The Salvation Army, a world-wide charity organization, was established in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1865

questions.question: The Great Exhibition, a symbol of the Victorian Age, was held in London in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1851

questions.question: Which Athenian sculptor, who worked almost exclusively with bronze, created the classic statue, The Discus Thrower?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Myron
